abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy I Project for
            Ethiopia were as follows: Bank performance was satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the energy assessments prepared under the
            joint United Nations Development Program (UNDP) and Bank
            energy sector management assistance program (ESMAP) played a
            crucial role in the design of both the Energy I project and
            the Energy II projects. It is important to keep the design
            of energy projects simple and avoid complex implementation
            arrangements, even within a single sub-sector. The
            project's experience in producing briquettes from crop
            residues had mixed results and did not lead to ongoing
            productive enterprises. A key element in a successful
            improved stove dissemination program is to pay detailed
            attention to producer capabilities, quality control, and
            consumer preferences. The implementation of viable
            industrial energy efficiency improvements requires follow-up
            efforts to train staff and may require the provision of
            special financing mechanisms to implement them. The
            project's experience suggests that the private sector
            is appropriate agent for the production of briquettes from
            crop wastes. The management of a project such as Energy I,
            project managers need to devote full time to their project
            management duties and should not have any other duties in
            the government, especially during the start-up phase.
